item.title: November 1st / Last Day of the World Series?
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Man, did  November come fast.  I was up at 4:45 to put together a cross bike and then pack my road bike to fly to California.  The cross bike took the longest.  I actually was riding gravel on it, so needed to switch the crankset to smaller rings.  I found some wheels that had pretty good tires glues on good.  I'm planning on racing in Louisville next weekend.  That is going to be ugly.  Okay, have to go.   Go Royals!

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Sure does look like it - KC won. First time since 1985.

item.title: Pretty Beat
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Yesterday wasn't exactly stress free. Â Getting all my stuff together for the next two weeks and then catching a flight was difficult. Â I think I'm more beat up from the Iowa roofing experience than I had anticipated. Â I wasn't working crazy hours. Â At least not crazy hours for me. Â But I was doing manual labor for 14 hours a day for 3 full days. Â I wasn't used to it. Â I did feel better waking up on Saturday morning than I did on Wednesday, so at least I was getting used to it. I got to watch most of the World Series game last night, which I didn't expect. Â I was surprised that the Royals won, coming back again in the 9th inning to tie the game. Â Seems like that is their modus operandi. Â  Anyway, it was big celebrations going on in Kansas City and the surrounding areas. Â Lots of fireworks, etc. Â There is going to be a big parade, which seems kind of strange, but that is the way cities do that nowadays. Â I guess always. Â They haven't won in 30 years, so it is sort of a big deal. The Mike Nosco Memorial Ride is tomorrow morning in Newbury Park, Ca. Â I've done the ride for the past 5 or so years. Â I love the route, riding along the ocean then zigzagging up and down canyons. Â It is wonderful. Â Plus, seeing old and new friends, getting to ride with them is super. The ride was created by Jack Nosco, Mike's brother and it is a beautiful tribute to him. I'm heading up to Jimmy Mac's house this afternoon. Â I don't see Mac anywhere nearly enough. He has been travelling the country the last month, so he is probably travelled out. Â Mac is in the Levis team photo from a couple days ago. Â I've know Mac nearly a quarter century and like I said above, don't get to hang with him near enough. Â It is supposed to rain later today, in SoCal, so I hope it doesn't screw up our one day of riding a year we have. Okay, that is about it from LA so far. Â I think I'll go stick my feet in the ocean before I head up to Somis. [caption id="attachment_37514" align="aligncenter" width="444"] The pilot said this was the grand canyon. I'm not sure it is, but it is dramatic. I love looking out the window flying.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37513" align="aligncenter" width="600"] But, in reality, the midwest is more interesting to me.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37512" align="aligncenter" width="600"] There are lots of beautiful flowers in Socal in November.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Say what now? Seriously, your pilot wasn't kidding--it's the Grand Canyon. You were almost directly above GC Village on South Rim. That's Sublime Point on the end of the green, center right, on north side. Was just hiking Kaibab Trail from North Rim last month, just out of the picture to right. Great trails, unparalleled scenery from above and below the rim.
Planning a rim-to-rim next fall, so I've been reading about the run/walk/jog/wog. Get this: the fastest ultra runners do the 22+ miles from S to N in under 3 hours, and the S-N-S, rim-to-rim-to-rim, out-and-back record is under 7 hrs, starting and ending on South Rim.
Start with 4400 ft drop in just 7 miles = quads are already hamburger. Then run a trail marathon with 6000 ft climb and descent. Then, after running almost 34 miles, climb back out = another 4400 ft climb in 7 miles.
Unless you do it N-S-N. Which leaves the steepest part, on North Kaibab, for the very end. Bonus.
I believe the Royals tied the game in the 8th?
Nice post.
Why would the pilot lie about the scenery below??
You forgot: and an hour/day to read and comment on this blog.

wish i could do only 3 hard days of work then take two weeks off.. lol..my crappy life= add 2 shitty commutes in there. cut the hours to 11-12 daily. then go work at a bar at nite.. oh, then try and cram in training.. and repeat 5-6 days a week. for years...

The heavens declare the glory of God, and the sky above proclaims His handiwork. Day to day pours out speech, and night to night reveals knowledge. Psalm 19:1-2. Nothing better than flying in a plane and seeing God declare His handiwork from 32,000 feet
Looks like the Grand Canyon to me! Not much else in this country would look like that from cruising altitude.

Todays post hits on some things pertinent in my life...
Not much better than staring out the window on a clear day at 37,000 feet, and that would be over any continent. The planet and its physical geography never ceases to amaze me.
Manual labor is something that requires training.; ie you need to do it everyday. Or else it hurts. Physical labor is a younger mans profession. As a general contractor, I see that the guys still in the field in their 50's are few and far between, and are the ones who learned to be super efficient with their physical output. That is to say they work smart. For the dummies like me who hit the project with unbridled physical gusto; well I and the rest have worn themselves out. Once in awhile I try to play in the field, and it always crushes me. Im not OK with that, but alas that is the process of aging and I am powerless against it.
Enjoy Socal and the memorial ride...Today is the last day of the three day celebration of the Dia de Los Muertos. In the US we call it the Day of the Dead. Sadly, I have quite a few good folks to remember, but right now Im thinking of my Dad. My family set up a small alter in memory of my Dad yesterday, a boy from Brooklyn who loved the Dodgers, and then the Mets. But foremost he loved the blue collar man and the blue collar sports team, so he would have been OK with KC's win. Congrats!
What is that old rider saying: ride instead of walk, sit instead of stand, lay instead of sitting, do roofing instead of sleeping? Something like that, may be tired but you paid it forward.

item.title: Mike Nosco Memorial Ride Morning
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded:
It is always too early waking up for this ride. Â Last night we hung out with Jimmy Mac and his wife Gale. Â I love those two. Â We went to our standard Italian restaurant, but it was closed on a Monday. Â Go figure.

Anyway, I am a bit underslept and chilled. Â I guess it has been super hot all fall here in Somis and the weather just broke. Â It is a damp 45 now, which is California terms is -10 degrees. I'm not exactly sure how far the ride is today. Â 80 something miles, but with tons of climbing. Long sustained climbs. Â I'm not sure how I'm going to feel, so I'll just play it by ear. Â There are over 1000 people riding, so there is always someone wanting to go my speed. Okay, this is a super way to spend a Tuesday, riding the canyons of the Santa Monica Mountains. Â I can't really think of anything else I'd rather be doing, which I don't take for granted. [caption id="attachment_37518" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Jimmy Mac has a tiki room in his house in Somis. It is super cool.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37519" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Jimmy Mac and Sue at sunset yesterday. Â It was my annual once a year ride with Mac. Â We got a little wet, but it felt pretty good.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Jimmy! I used to work with JMac back in the Husky days. Pink shirts and keyboard necktie. Always smiling and rockin the latest new wave music. Never a bad word to say about anyone. Great influence, great memories.
Haven't seen Jimmy Mac in years but I still hear his laugh.

1000 people show up for a ride on a TUESDAY? Amazing. Jimmy Mac's one of the nicest guys in the biz. I hope SoCal's flood season's not too severe this year as I'll be out there in about 5 weeks. I hope to avoid the other 3 SoCal seasons (fire, earthquake and riot) as well!

item.title: Mike Nosco Memorial Ride
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Yesterday was a blast like usual.  The Mike Nosco ride is one of my favorite days of the year always.  Riding bikes for a good cause with a ton of friends and potential friends is pretty hard to beat. I had a sort of weird day, but it turned out fine.  Jack, Mike's brother and the organizer of the ride, made a speech at the start and we took off.  The rides goes 10 or so miles down the road to an intersection close to where his brother was killed in a traffic accident.  Then the real ride begins. This year the group didn't spend much time there.  But while I was at the corner, I looked down and had a zillion goat heads in my tires.  I thought, shit, I flatted for sure.  I got off my bike and pull each one out and put some spit on the hole.  I had to dig a few out of the rubber that were deep.  I pulled them all out and thought maybe I just lucked out. There were about 50 people there putting in new tubes.  I was riding sewups and only had one spare tire.  Anyway, we take off and the ride starts riding to the coast.  A couple miles later, my front tire is flat.  Shit.  So, I pull over and change the tire.  I was so cool seeing so many people ride by. I get back on my bike and start down the coast towards the Deer Creek climb.  It was wicked tailwind and I was going close to 30 most of the way. I catch a bunch of guys and then turn up Deer Creek.  Deer Creek is just 3 miles long, but super steep.  I rode it pretty steady and realized I wasn't going that great.  I wasn't going bad, just couldn't get into sync.  My legs felt sort of weird. I kept going pretty steady back down the coast and then the next climb is Mulholland.  I tried to ride it steady too, but a little harder.  I got passed by one guy and he was going pretty good.  He got about 100 meters ahead of me and then we seemed to be going about the same speed.  I was just looking for a group, or someone I knew to ride with, but I was too far back in the group of 1000 riders still  I kept going by hoards of riders. About 2/3's the way up I got up to the one guy that was going pretty good.  There was a strave climbing section of the ride there and he was obviously going for it.   So I pulled by him and started pulling pretty hard.  It was fun.  He came through a couple times, but I was going better at this point.  Near the top we came upon Sue.  I told her I'd wait at the top of the climb.  We keep going hard and he sprinted the KOM finish sign.   Then he introduced himself and another ride memory had been created for both of us. The top of Mulholland is about 1/2 way through the ride.  We still had to descend back to the coast highway, then climb Latigo and ride back to Newbury Park.  I rode with Sue the last couple hours, sometimes with other guys in a group, sometimes not.  It was super. It was a super day on the bike, but I didn't have a super day physically.  Early on I had to take my gloves off because my thumb was killing me.  Then I never really got going.  I don't know if taking 4 days off is the reason, being a little stale. Whatever the reason, last night my left hip started aching.  And now this morning I'm limping pretty good.  It must be a muscle deal, but I don't know what I did different to bring that on. Luckily, I'm flying to Louisville for the Derby Cup, and staying with my friend Stacy who is an orthopedic surgeon, so I can get both my thumb and hip checked out. I entered the Louisville UCI cyclocross last night and the race predictor has me predicted to finish last in both races.  It shouldn't be that hard to beat that prediction I'd hope.  Maybe it is because I haven't done a cross race the last three seasons?   And it was sort of weird, I entered the racing at the USA Cycling website and then when I went to see the race predictor, I was entered twice.  So I went to my credit card bill and it was charged twice.  I'm not sure what that was all about, but I hope someone catches it and it isn't a hassle. The day was great, but I can't skip the LA traffic bit.  LA traffic sucks.  Like really sucks.  I don't understand how people can live in a place where they don't know whether it is ging to take them 2 hours or 6 to get somewhere?  Maybe, being from Kansas, I just don't know the super secret ways of avoiding it, but it is a real downside to this place. Anyway, there was virtually no traffic on the ride.  Especially on the climbs.  Jimmy Mac came out on his motorcycle and I saw him a few times taking pictures.  One is below.  The scenery was amazing.  It continually amazes me each year. [caption width="600" id="attachment_37527" align="aligncenter"] Riding along the coast after I flatted early.  Jimmy Mac going by.[/caption][caption width="600" id="attachment_37528" align="aligncenter"] Jack Nosco at the Mulholland sag stop.[/caption][caption width="481" id="attachment_37526" align="aligncenter"] A photo Jimmy Mac took of me climbing Latigo I think.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Your right Jack I did not see you or hear you lol. I always get my ass handed to me on the climbs ðŸ˜œ So im always playing catch up ðŸ™. But I can say we've got your back if you need anything and our thoughts are with you more than you know .

The weed(s) that yield goat-headed thorns: I'm in favor of entirely purging them from the earth.

I had to come to Colorado to learn about goatheads. Never encountered them in SoCal or the Bay Area. Just lucky in that regard I guess?
Only once road tubulars for training in goathead country. You pretty much have to be sponsored to consider it. This was fresh off a two month bike tour with all sorts of low end grunt power in my legs. First or second time on an unloaded bike after getting back.
Still remember that ride like it was yesterday too.
Very common in AZ too (or any dry climate). Actually, AZ should ideally be the HQ for all makers of inner tubes, as we've got a million species of thorn.
Thanks for it all Steve. You bring back some good memories. Dean P.

The reason we put up with the traffic is the very mountains you were riding on on Tuesday and because we can ride in summer kits in November... ;)
Yes...we do have the super secret info...it's called Waze...get the app...use it. .....you're welcome.

I was going to try to stay with you though not knowing the route and knowing I was yet halfway through I decided to keep it at nice steady tempo. What a great cause, ride, and route; weather was epic. Best of luck in your upcoming races, and I am sure you will beat the face predictor.

Was great to ride with you a bit and enjoyed your piece on the Wankmaster. You and I had a brief conversation about Wanky up Latigo.

Hi Steve! I was so happy to see you and Sue out there again, though disappointed I only caught glimpses of you both and no chance to chat! Yeah, definitely one of the best days of the year always! Hi Trudi! :~)

item.title: The Cycling Tribe
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: I had a bunch of time to ride by myself on the Nosco ride and think about things that have been mulling around my brain. Â I was thinking how much I enjoyed the last two times I've been in Southern California. Â And it wasn't only for the riding, which was great, but also for the interactions. A couple weeks ago I flew out here for the South Bay Wheelmen team banquet. Â Here I made a new friend, Seth Davidson. Â This guy is the real deal. Â I instantly liked him. I'm really not sure what Seth's background is in cycling. Â And I really don't understand him enough to know what drives him. Â But his is a very important cog in cycling in LA. Seth asked me to come and speak for a bit at the banquet. Â I thought it would be a "normal" bike club season finale. Â But, no, nothing Seth does is normal. Â He had the new Strand Brewery reserved and ready to house the 100's of people that were there. Seth was dressed in a tuxedo and was very at ease in the roll of master of ceremonies. Â Seth gave out a ton of "wacky awards" to lots of different folks involved in South Bay cycling. Â He knew them all personally. Anyway, when I was preparing to talk, I had scribbled a bunch of notes down on a piece of paper, but when I got up to the stage, I decided to just wing it. Â That was mainly because of the day I'd experienced and Seth. See, Seth had told me this story about a girl on the Donut ride, a girl I had noticed and asked about. Â She was dressed in knickers and a black jersey, with her seat a few centimeters too high. She seemed out of place compared to the rest of us. Â But she was hanging tough, riding much better than "her looks" would predict. Seth told me he was out riding around Palos Verdes early one morning, like 5 am early, and came upon this girl who was out riding with no lights, dressed in all black. Â And she was going pretty good. Â He told her she needed to show up at the Donut Ride on Saturdays to learn the sport. Â And she did, and has. Â She had shown up for the past two months and was going better and better. This got me thinking about my meeting with Derek Bouchard-Hall, the CEO of USAC. Â He is a smart guy and said the most surprising discovery of his personal fact finding mission was that our sport, cycling, was really just a huge collection of volunteers. Â Guys like Seth who make the sport what it is. And Derek is right. Â Our sport isn't the Tour de France. Â  It is a eclectic collection of people that have a passion for cycling. Â And many don't have anything to do with racing. Â Guys that are building the new Danky Dank trail up in Cable Wisconsin. Â  Or the guys grooming the single track for fat bike riding in the winter. Â  Or 1000's upon 1000's of other people that are doing their small part to make the sport better for all of us. These are guys like Seth. Â Here is a guy that uses his own money to throw a banquet for his cycling friends, just because he thinks it is important. Â And a Â guy that will go out of his way to bring a new rider into his tribe, because he thinks it will benefit them. Â Not him, but them. We are so lucky to have so many Seth Davidsons in our sport. Â It would survive without them.   PS - I didn't realize this, but Seth has his own cycling blog. Â I just found it. Â He actually wrote a super nice write up about me on it a couple days ago. Â I'm going to have to go back and read all of what he writes. Â Here is a link, check it out. [caption id="attachment_37534" align="aligncenter" width="480"] Seth is action at the Wanky awards.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Steve you may not remember, but I found Seth's blog from a link you provided to his site back during the whole Meeker mess. Laugh out loud funny writer, kept me coming back to his blog. Thank you.

"Tribe"is a perfect description of the community that Seth has cultivated in the South Bay area of Los Angeles. Fresh off the plane from KC, his welcoming demeanor and self-deprecating sense of humor on group rides has made my relocation LA so enjoyable. Every city needs a Seth.

There was some early mind warping by Fields and the Dickson brothers. Not sure who else aided in the bending of Seth's mind other than consider who was around in the early '80s down in Austin TX, I'd guess the seasonal Wintering folks were the oddest.
Seths blog has been my second favorite blog next to yours for a while now. He is a great writer!
Great piece by Seth. And from those that know you, he was spot on.
The two Blogs I read every morning. Thanks to both of you.

, cycling, was really just a huge collection of volunteers Does he mean the parts of the sport that are actually growing? Derek isn't working for free. How about those local associations? They don't work for free. I'm still not sure what will be accomplished as Thom still runs the federation.
Rider down. A member of the tribe that you wrote warmly about is in trouble. Jocelyn Lovell is on life support. http://www.velocipedesalon.com/forum/f2/sad-news-39478.html
Sorry, wrong link. Try this one: http://www.velocipedesalon.com/forum/f2/sad-news-42772.html

: (
I remember reading the article in Winning magazine when I was in high school. No doubt about it, he is one of the greats. Be well, dude.
Omg.. seth and you are so cool..

"Nothing Seth does is normal" is an understatement; That he is a very important cog in cycling in LA, is an even bigger one! Seth is one of a kind. He brings us together, ties us together, describes and thereby defines our little world with his words. We are so lucky to have Seth Davidsons in our sport. Thank you for attending and speaking at the 2015 South Bay Cycling Awards, and thank you for the article!

item.title: Louisville UCI Cross Weekend
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: It rained all night here in Louisville. Â Well, I'm not sure it was actually all night, but it rained hard when I was aware of it. Â  I haven't had a chance to get to the course yet, but I'm assuming it is going to be muddy for the pre-ride this afternoon. I haven't raced a cyclocross for 2 years. Â I'm actually thinking the last cross race I did was two years ago here in Louisville. Â But, that might be wrong. Â I know I haven't done Nationals for the past two seasons, so it has been a while since I'm raced cross. I haven't even tried any cross technique. Â I'm hoping that the limestone rock stairs at the Eva Bandman Cyclocross Park aren't wet or muddy when I'm racing tomorrow night at 6. Â My broken hip still isn't up to speed when my foot slips on stuff. Â Especially when I'm under pressure. Â  That is my biggest worry. Â My hip has ached some the past week, but I'm going to have Stacie look at it today. Tonight there is a "gathering" at Stacie's house. Â It is a party for.....I'm not really sure. Â Here is a link to the announcement. Â Katie Compton, Ryan Trebon and a bunch of other riders are going to be there. Â Actually, there are going to be close to 100 people here, so it is going to be a bit chaotic. Â I'm going to try not to be too stressed for this weekend. Â Baby steps. I say that and I am already sort of stressed because I only have one bike with me. Â And that one might be a little suspect. Â Suspect because I haven't really ridden it at all since making it back into a cyclocross bike from gravel road bike. Â I'm hesitant to go over to the park and ride today when it is probably going to be completely different tomorrow, especially tomorrow night at 6 after all the other races have changed the course up. Okay. Â I need to get going. Â I'm hoping to sneak in and get an x-ray of my thumb. Â It has been nearly a month now since I squished it and it still is super tender. Â I'm not really sure why I want to know because it is very doubtful that I'll do anything Â about it even if it is diagnosed as being jacked up. Â I know it is jacked up. I'll post some photos of the race course if I drive by there soon. [caption id="attachment_37541" align="aligncenter" width="640"] I slept a ton last night. I've been feeling a little off the last couple days. Karl made me quinoa vegetable soup for 2nd breakfast today.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37539" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Trudi and Stacie waiting at the airport.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37540" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Stacie gave Trudi a Tiffany charm necklace with Bromont's picture in it. So nice.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Mr. Tilford, sir, the "race predictor" has you as DFL both days. I suppose you know that or you would not be giving us the "woe is me blues". Look at it this way; all you gotta do is finish second to last to exceed expectations. I predict you finish at least tenth from the bottom if you stick it out. You're a stud.
You might be better off with a hip replacement. Don't know if they do thumb replacements, though.

Hey Steve, this is Carina. I met you on your flight from San Diego. My nana's funeral really was more of a celabration of her life. It was beautiful. It really was awesome taliking to you. It put my mind at ease regarding my nana and gave me a groovy story to tell my daughter when I get home. I hope you do well in your next event and keep being the cool person that you are. Blessings!
steve, for a guy thats been racing 40 years you sure are ill prepared a lot of times heading into races.

Hey Cycling Fans and Mr. Tilford Chris Froome here I just wanted to say that my upcoming, very last Tweet is going to be something like this- "I love cycling, I love it sooooo bloody much, I love everything about it- Sir Brailsford, not hurting on climbs, hippos and even Richie Porte! Nothing compares to me."
Ok, I might have stolen some of this- but I plan it in "iambic pentameter" (per Dave).

Steve--I have a very similar hip injury. You gotta do PT. I had the same mindset as you: I don't need PT because I am going to be active riding, hiking, construction, etc. so I will be hitting all the necessary movements and muscles without PT. Unfortunately, that is not the case. Get some targeted exercises and stick to them for 2-3 months. I promise it will make all the difference in the world.
FSonicSmith - be sure to wave to the crowd from the podium - - oh, you are not even racing?

I had the same injury too. PT was essential to the recovery. Even after my initial outpatient PT was complete, I'd noticed weird little things like trouble navigating in and around furniture in the house, plus "subtle" movements of my leg that I should normally have no trouble doing. It was difficult to articulate. But I started riding with a guy who was a PT, and he mentioned a word I'd never heard before:
Proprioception: The sense of the relative position of neighboring parts of the body and strength of effort being employed in movement. It's what lets us jump, walk up and down stairs, run and walk, without breaking our legs in the process. It tells the muscles what level of tense to create for the situation. Mine was all messed up from the injury. Here are some links:
https://www.google.com/#q=proprioception+exercises+hip
To echo Rich W: You've gotta do the homework, or things won't go back to normal. I'm 14 years out now, and my hip is not 100% of what it used to be, but it's pretty darn close now. I also went ahead with hardware removal surgery, which meant 18 months of no bike racing-type activity (to let all the holes fill-in and ossify properly).

Thanks Krak.
Similar story. I had my knee done couple of years ago. Did a lot of therapy. Strength is back. Speed is back. Left leg balance is a little still off. Exercises continue. Just getting back into the bike racing (mountain bike). We'll see what happens this spring.

item.title: Louisville Morning
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Last night my friend Stacie organized a Pro party for youth cyclocross here in Louisville. Â It is amazing the schedule that woman keeps. Â I had a little glimpse of some of her day yesterday and it was crazy. I went to her office mid day to get a x-ray of my thumb. Â Her office was a zoo. Â An organized zoo, crazy busy, but manageable, I guess. Turns out my thumb is broken. Â But, I knew that already. Â It still hurts pretty much, but nothing like it did 2 weeks ago. Â Plus, there is nothing that I have to do differently, so that is great. I came back to her house to get ready to ride. Â I was thinking I had all this time, but I didn't realize that I hadn't reset my watch from Chicago and it was off an hour. Â So all of a sudden 2:30 became 3:30. Â And the get together was starting at 6. I hurried and rode down the RIver Road over to the course. Â It had rained over an inch I hear, so expected it to be pretty soupy. Â At the bike wash, most of the bikes were pretty muddy, but not clogged up. Â But they were riding the whole course. Â I just rode the top section that serpentines up and down the hill. Â It was slick, but not muddy. I really didn't put any effort into getting the lines down because it was going to be so much different today at 6. Anyway, I hightail it back to Prospect, which is 11 miles, and just get back in time to shower and get ready for the party. There were close to 100 people here. Â Lots of good food, wine, beer, etc. Â There were so many kids. Â And the U of Louisville cycling team had representation. There were a lot of really good riders that were on the panel for questions. Â Katie Compton, Ryan Trebon,Â Gage Hecht,Â Kaitlin Antonneau, Gavin Haley, Dan Timmerman, Jake Wells, Ally Stacher and a few others. It was super knowledgable group and there was a lot of information that was exchanged. Â Every race should have a meet and greet party like this. Today is going to be done in a blink. Â It is already late morning, I'm still on California time, and it is T-7 hours to race time. Â I'm going to suit up and do the 30 minute ride over to the course and do a couple laps between races. I have no illusions on how I'm going to do here. Â I very much doubt I'll survive the 80% rule, which I think is bullshit. Â I haven't seen the sandpit and am hoping it doesn't jack up my drivetrain too much. Â Mike Crum left a comment yesterday about being unprepared for all the racing I've done. Â He is absolutely correct this time. Â I am super unprepared. Â I haven't dismounted or mounted a cyclocross bike in two years and didn't have enough time to get the correct equipment together for my liking. Â But I felt that I need to get back into the race scene and this was the first opportunity. Â I'll be better in a month or so. Yeah, some stories of the chosen one would be great to read..

Good luck to you sir. You're one tough hombre. When your schedule settles down and you have some time to write and reflect a bit, it would be great to hear a story about you racing or training with LeMond back in the day - maybe a day where you got the better of him. I hear he had a tendency to get a little soft in the off season. All us quickly aging hacks out here love your tales about the the old days...

item.title: Louisville Day 1
item.dc:creator: tilford97

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I think that's damned impressive given two years of no cross racing, lack of mounts/dismounts practice, injury, etc. Someone gave me some shit for my previous post about "race predictor". "Race predictor" is silly-we all know that-and I don't think that post should have been interpreted as a jab at you. Anyhow, I went back and read your post from back in May of 2014 when you broke your hip. I saw that Paul Martin came to you and offered help. I have raced against Paul Martin here in Ohio. He is one of our local heroes, holds course records, super nice guy, a stud on the road, Mr. good looks, wife is hot, kids are good looking, he's a lawyer, yada yada. Then I did a search under "Paul Martin" and saw your history of feuding so to speak with he and his teammates regarding aggressive riding. Just wondering-have you patched things up with the Netherland Rubber nee Panther Trucking guys, Texas Roadhouse guys, etc? Or do you see those guys infrequently enough that there is no need to worry about it?

Funny recollection w your shoe dilemma. At Il Ciocca worlds in 91, the Italian national team were coming around every CC lap w goo-muck everywhere except their shoes...which were spotless. Turns out that up in an obscure location on the CC course,the Italian support staff were fully stocked w replacement shoes for every one of their riders....swapping on every lap to allow for efficient clip in . Caused quite the rhubarb at the nightly UCI meeting...being at the time there was the no outside support for riders other than feed-hydrate in effect.

item.title: Post Cross Doldrums
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Driving 10 hours yesterday I had a bunch of time to think about last weekend in Louisville.  I decided I probably should have started my return to cyclocross racing at a local event rather than racing against the best guys in the country, starting at the back.  It is not good for my mental health getting throttled that badly two days in a row. The carnage at the back of the fields in those races is crazy.  It isn't really anyone's particular fault.  There are just a lot of riders and not that much space.  The Saturday night race was stupid the first couple hundred meters on the grass.  A pile up in the first corner, then again just a bit later in the dark mud pit.  I kind of missed all that, other than losing a buckle on one of my shoes, but still, the distance you lose there is terrible. My running stinks.  I wouldn't even call it running.  But, two out of three run ups on the course were pretty steep, with big steps, and that is the worst for my broken hip.  I am pleasantly surprised that my hip seems good from the weekend, even though it was twisted around on Sunday when my foot got stuck in Jacob's front wheel. I wasn't riding that badly.  I wasn't going great, but I wasn't gasping for air or anything like that.  My bike handling skills were subpar though.  Those will get better. I can't believe how many guys were riding disc brakes.  I guess that is the direction the sport has gone and it isn't reversing.  It seems like a hassle to me, but I'm old school in a lot of ways of the sport.  Removing rotors to fly, or just to pack wheels into the back of a car is going to suck.  Or just having cross specific wheels, training and race, is a big issue to most riders. Anyway, I felt okay yesterday.  My right knee got pretty twisted on Sunday and it is aching some, but nothing serious.  I got back a little after 5 pm, and my brother had organized a gravel night time ride at 5:30, so I had to rush.  I only had to put bottle cages and light on my cross bike and was in business. Riding at night, especially on narrow trails, (we started on a bike path), seems super fast.  It was way colder than I had expected.  It was in the lower 60's when I got back, but was in the lower 50's as soon as the sun set.  I had bare legs and never really got warm. I sort of felt like riding harder, maybe pent-up frustration from the weekend, I don't know, but whatever the reason, I ended up pulling most the whole way.  It seemed so late, but even after a couple mechanicals and riding two hours we got back before 8.  Man, it sure is dark then. Anyway, I'm not sure what I'm doing now.  I have to work on my van some.  I'm thinking I need a new fuel pump and the transmission is okay.  At least that is my thoughts now.  The problem with this is that auto repair involves use of thumbs, which I am short of one.  My right one, which is worse.  I can probably get by, but we'll see. [caption width="450" id="attachment_37587" align="aligncenter"] The sensations of riding at night are great.[/caption] [caption width="450" id="attachment_37588" align="aligncenter"] They were harvesting a lot last night. I didn't realize how much stuff goes into the air when they do this. Probably the reason for the great fall sunsets.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Wow, that spectator turnout looks dismal. Really sad to see. Cross is TOO MUCH of a participation only sport in this country. People don't even care to watch the most elite people in the nation do it. Meanwhile, tickets to the NFL game are on StubHub for $320/piece.
Steve, you planning on racing Tulsa weekend after next? Sounds like a fun weekend of racing from the Tulsa Tough guys. Hope to see you there.
Oops that was meant for the previous blog post!
I see your problem. You're making cyclocross very difficult by riding with buckets on your shoes.
Thumbs up
Dude, don't be so hard on yourself. There's maybe five 55 year old riders in the entire world who could ride in UCI pro cross races. Enjoy your posts!!

Steve, you mentioned switching you bike from gravel mode to cross mode for Louisville. I'd be interested in what changes you make. Just tires?
I'd like an all-arounder bike. There are "gravel" bikes and cross bikes, and I'm not sure which I'd prefer. It seems the main difference is frame geo (and Steve's not switching frames!).

Speaking of removing rotors. Can anyone tell me why in the hell the industry settled on Torx bolts as opposed to button head Allen bolts for mounting rotors? I HATE the fuck out of those things! I run centerlock hubs/rotors for that very reason.

Torx heads can take more repeated torque due to more points of engagement. Ever round off a button head with an allen wrench at a slight angle due to dirt inside the head and have to drill it out? Wouldn't happen with torx.
Makes sense "in theory" but my personal experience has been the opposite. Oh well. Thanks

I ride a Trek Boone non-disc for gravel, cx & road bike racing. It rocks all 3 modes from 150+ rough gravel races, to smooth pavement. Excellent all-around geometry that works for me. I just switch the wheels/tires for each. Easier & cheaper to have 2-3 extra sets of wheels & tires than that many bikes:)
Clearance. Those higher surface area torx heads don't need to be as tall as Allen bolts to handle the torque necessary for rotors.
Yes, but it's more fun to have 9 bikes.

The headline should read,
Steve Tilford rejoins CX after injury hiatus!!!

Steve, CX takes a lot of snap to accelerate out of each turn...more so than a Crit or MTB race. You've been away for 2 years...you'll get better with practice. Now go practice then come to Asheville, NC in January for Nationals and win another Age Group Championship jersey.
Thanks Erik. That's similar to what I'm looking for, only no "crabon." ;^)
One thumb up ... the other doesn't work

item.title: Getting Sick
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: I'm constantly worried about getting sick. Â I don't think I'm a hypochondriac or anything, I'm just an athlete and one of the biggest concerns of an athlete is staying healthy. Fall is one of those times that have been tough for me. Â I've historically been a sickly guy. Â I'm not sure is it is because I don't have a spleen, which filters blood, allergies, or what, but I've hadÂ some doozy illnesses over the years. I used to always get sick early season. Â And stay sick for at least a month. Â I'd go through a couple rounds of antibiotics, coughing yellow and brown stuff for weeks. Â Nothing seemed to help until the weather turned dry. I think this was just really bad allergies. Â But I don't see the difference between allergies and illness. Â Your body and energy level is the same, so I just call it sick. I've been healthier recently. Â Maybe since I did sinus surgery a while back. Â I think breathing through your nose when you sleep is important. Especially in the winter when the heater is running. Â Whatever the reason, I don't get quite so many lung infections as I used to. But I've been replacing those long term lung infections with stomach issues. Â At least a couple times a year, the last few years, I've had a stomach bout. Â Again, I have no idea why this has started, but I'm okay with it somewhat. Â It doesn't last anywhere nearly as long as lung issues and my fitness level doesn't drop to the bottom of the scale. Trudi is exactly the opposite of me. Â She hardly ever gets sick. Â And if she does, she gets well in no time. Â Like she can be sick for a day or two and call it terrible. Trudi is sick now, which means I'm am sick, or am going to get sick. Â As soon as Trudi gets sick, virtually every time, I'm sick within a day or two. Â And I stay sick forever, while she is well almost immediately. We got flu shots yesterday, but she told me she was feeling under the weather before that. Â She seems like she has a head cold, but I feel more generally rundown. Catherine turned me onto Colostum. Â  Her mom uses it for nearly every illness imaginable. Â The stuff she gets is at Akins. Â I realized it is most likely placebo effect, but I've stayed well a few times when I was sure I was going to be ill, so it worked somehow. Anyway, the changing of seasons is a tricky time for athletes. Â There is so much more stuff in the air in the fall and we are all just starting to get cooped up together, so the chances of spreading sickness is much higher. Â And once we get sick, it is so much harder to regain the fitness losses because of weather, shorter days and such. Hopefully, I'll avoid Trudi's sickness this time, but I'm not holding my breath on it.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I've had several doctors tell me one of the best things you can do for your body is to eat a yogurt every day. Makes no difference what brand.

Hope you feel better soon! My wife and myself are almost like Trudy and you in that regard.
Expect I'm more like Trudy and my wife is more like you. My wife isn't an athlete.
Being sick sucks wishing you a speedy recovery.

Steve, It is well documented that immune function is depressed for up to 72 hours in endurance athletes post training or post competition, and may become chronically depressed without adequate recovery time on an ongoing basis. This makes endurance athletes especially susceptible to viruses or bacterial infections especially in the upper respiratory tract. It's just the downside of being an athlete... this immune system effect is also exacerbated by not enough sleep, stress, and the rest of the usual contributors to a weakened immune system. Here's an article on the respiratory effects. My tri friends are always dealing with colds and flu due to the intense nature of their training. They do win all of their events however. http://www.nature.com/icb/journal/v78/n5/abs/icb200074a.html

a quality probiotic each day may help with the bad stomach stuff, vitamin D is supposed to be very good for the immune system, more so than C they might be saying now...even though you are older, it might be something to consider to go to a good allergy doctor and start allergy shots, I have been getting shots for years, never get sick.

item.title: Floor Pumps
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: I have gone through a ton of pumps in my lifetime.  And each and everyone initially seems like it is "the pump", then it just becomes another one that is eventually going to fail me at a very inopportune time.  And anytime is inopportune when you need to pump up your tires. I'm talking mainly about floor pumps.  I really don't put too much emphasis on hand pumps any more.  I'd have to just state categorically that there isn't a good hand pump available nowadays. Silca hand pumps were cheap plastic, but worked great.  When I rode for Schwinn, our frame pumps were painted the same as our bikes.  That was pretty cool. But, since then, I have never had an adequate frame pump. I think anyone my age started their career with an orange Silica floor pump.  These were the pumps of choice for years.  They were serviceable, with replacement leather washers readily available, plus replacement rubber washer for the pump head too.  They were pretty bomb proof. The pressure gauge never seemed to fail and with the availability of the two parts that wore out, the pumps would last forever. But, the industry started coming up with newer, "better" pumps.  Pumps that were dual action, putting air in on the downstroke and upstroke.  Huge volume pumps.  Ones that would take 5 strokes to fill a tire.  But these pumps, all of them, never aged appropriately.  They would wear out so quickly, that you soon forgot how well they initially worked. I went through a huge amount of Blackburn pumps.  I had a slew of them, think I won them or something, but they were substantial and seemed like they were going to be great.  But no, they failed big time.  I actually saved all of them and have been meaning to send them back to Blackburn and say that they should be ashamed to have produced such a product.  One that woos the consumer with beauty and function, only to fail dismally. When I was riding for Specialized, I had a bunch of their floor pumps.  They worked adequately, but eventually their feet would break off.  I think they were made of the same aluminum as their frames were and they were too brittle to last, just like their frames. Recently, I had a nice Park pump.  It was holding up great and the chuck would grab ahold of just about any valve stem, no matter how short.  But alas, right when I need it the most, the night before Berryman, it sprung a leak. Bill Woodul was a pump snob.  He was a snob concerning a lot of things.  He used to search for old floor pumps out of Rolls Royces.  They came in the trunk and were beautiful.  I'm not sure if they worked very well, but they looked cooler than shit.  I think they were dual action too, taking 9 or so pumps to get to 115 psi. I don't really throw away my old floor pumps.  I'm not sure why that is.  I think I have the intention of fixing them, but very rarely do that anymore.  I'm not even sure if these pumps have parts that are replaceable.  Most don't I'd assume. I have never had the opportunity to use the new Silca $$$$ pump.  Josh Poertner, previously of Zipp, bought the rights to Silca and produced a Rolls Royce type of pump.  Here's a link to that story.   Maybe it is the one? So the quest for the elusive perfect floor pump continues.  But, it isn't that active.  Unless I happen to win the pump or happen upon it, I doubt that it will be successful.   But that is the thing with quests, you don't have to ever complete them to enjoy the adventure. [caption width="236" id="attachment_37610" align="aligncenter"] The go-to pump, the original Silca. It eventually came in a bunch of different colors, black, even pink, but orange was the most common.[/caption] [caption width="480" id="attachment_37609" align="aligncenter"] I'm using this pump now. I won it at Chequamegon. I didn't take the packaging off because I had no intention of using it much, but that hasn't panned out.[/caption] [caption width="480" id="attachment_37608" align="aligncenter"] Fix for the Specialized pump.[/caption] [caption width="600" id="attachment_37607" align="aligncenter"] A couple pumps that had potential, but didn't work out.[/caption] [caption width="234" id="attachment_37606" align="aligncenter"] The Rolls Royce pump.[/caption] [caption width="600" id="attachment_37611" align="aligncenter"] The new Silca floor pump. Just maybe?[/caption]   Home Depot pumps today.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have two of the old Silca floor pumps. I replaced the cheap heads with good brass presta heads right from the start. I have one at home, and keep the other in my car (along with some spare tubes and tires) in case I encounter any broken-down riders on the road. Also, the Silca mini-pumps are great to keep in a jersey pocket. Better than any other mini-pump I've ever used.
100% agreement

This pump head fits a number of generic floor pumps. I bought a bike shop floor pump (maybe rebadged Park?) for $30-something dollars about ten years ago. The head went out after 6 years and I replaced the head with this one, and haven't had an issue since. https://jet.com/product/detail/6336887f4e7f40d9941da669ecb1f9ba?jcmp=pla:ggl:brands_toys_games_a3:toys_pretend_play_toy_tools_a3_other:na:na:na:na:na:2&code=PLA15&k_clickid=55cc3daa-a024-47a4-9894-0d831906f3fe&gclid=Cj0KEQiAjpGyBRDgrtLqzbHayb8BEiQANZauhyOCignAhJ_UPMHfGpvcVIxHGBGzUu13Hl4k6ddYcuIaAoHw8P8HAQ

I don't recall the brand of my floor pump, but it is probably 15 years old and wtill works great. My frame pump is a Zefal HP-X series. Every years I break it down, oil the washer and put it back together. It is now at least 20 years old. I do not want to think of what will happen if I lose it or it finally breaks down as is hands-down the best frame pump I've ever used (I've used others with other riders).
The Topeak pocket rocket hand pump is great. I never use co2 unless i'm racing a mtb. Mine has pumped up 100's of flats of mine and my mates.

Steve,
I own one of the old Silca's and to this day it still functions very very well. As for the new Silca pumps. We have one in the office here at backcountry. and it works just well and fine but I'll have to write a review in 30 years to see if it spans the test of time.

I have used the Performance Bike "Hurricane" line of pumps for approx. 15 years. Lifetime warranty. I bought ONE pump, and I've brought 5 or 6 of them back in to be replaced, no questions asked.
Silca was the only "good" pump ever sold (IMHO). The frame pumps were only good if you bought a replacement Campagnolo head for them, tho. I use quickfills today.

What's wrong with the original SILCA? Both original and modern parts are available to rebuild 'em. Like you I went through plenty of freebie newfangled "smart pumps" which quickly died, bringing me back to the old original, reliable Silca. Of course you could spring for the new ULTIMATE - which makes you look around for tires to air up! It's that nice. The only issue with it is worrying about someone borrowing it....forever. I've been pestering Josh since its debut to come up with a "Chorus" version to complement the current "Super Record". One with the same quality barrel and guts, but without the fancy wood handles and colored hose and a more friendly price tag. But in these days of $15K bikes, a $500 pump's not too much different than a $2000 bike and $50 pump from back-in-the-day?

I still use my Silca Track pump that I bought 30 years ago on sale for $29. I've only had to replace the pump gasket once in all that time. The chuck gaskets would last around 2-3 years until I started to use only tubes with non-threaded valve stems. (then they seem to last forever) Silca frame pumps really sucked. Once you got over 85psi you had to really grunt to get close to 100. The old Zefal HPX was much better for getting over 100psi. Been using CO2 for the last 15-20 years. Only downside is that you better let out most of the CO2 when you get home and re-pump with air. CO2 leaks out of a butyl tube as fast as air leaks out of a latex tube.
http://www.npr.org/2014/09/24/351246933/what-makes-a-bike-pump-worth-450
Unfortunately, the guy's target customer for that product needs the gauge at the top so they can read it without their glasses. ;)
Still have the Silca blue floor pump I got back in 1984, works fine.

I bought a Zefal Husky in 1992 or so that held up beautifully for about 20 years until the hose developed a bunch of leaks. Cast iron base, leather washer in the cylinder, nice wood handle with plenty of handroom.
LEZYNE

RE the husky
Still available in SKS's line. Still don't like the folding feet, and the combi head wasn't as nice as the Topeak one.
The Topeak high-end one worked beautifully until it didn't (bleed valve started leaking). The gauge is accurate, though.
The silca track pumps? Gauge is inaccurate, or becomes so quickly. Otherwise, they're great, though they're short, and you'll spend plenty of time pumping as a result. I replaced the thirty-year-old press-on head with a Hirame.
The HPX (now "classic") wins the "Republic of insects and grass" award for frame pump post-doomsday durability and effectiveness.
Cheers,
Will
William M. deRosset Fort Collins, CO
I wonder whatever happened to that titanium wheel truing stand Woodul got from the Soviets?

You don't mention zefal - and I've always been a big fan. I like their aluminum frame pumps - not even sure if they're still available? But I always thought it was about the only thing French that was superior to ...(insert any other country here)-made items.
I just go to the corner gas station and fill up my Huffy's tires, once a month. Works great!

Not sure why this should be. Leak rate should be inversely proportional to the square root of density and CO2 is about 1.5 x as dense as air, so air should leak about 25% faster than CO2. However, I have noticed that I can never get a tire higher than about 80 psi with a CO2 cartridge, so maybe you're just seeing that low pressure when you get home and pump up with air.
I have the same pump. I bought in 1997 and just developed a tiny hose leak this summer after 18 years of totally trouble-free use. Anybody know if parts for this pump are available?
Michael- I've had a bunch of Zefal pump. Their floor pumps were just middle of the road, but lasted a long time. Their frame pumps, as previously stated here, are pretty good.
Dave-C02 definitely doesn't stay in a tire very long. I always deflate the tire when I get home and refill it with regular air.

Zefal frame pumps are pretty good as everyone knows. Park's "one-size-fits-all" pump is pretty good too, though I don't have any that are really old to compare with the longevity of Zefal. Silca's new IMPERO is...well...the Ferrari of frame pumps...with a price to match.

Same for Bike Nashbar pumps, they have a lifetime guarantee. Had one of their top of the line L'Orange pumps from 2009, when it broke this year they took back for a full refund and I bought the newest version which seems like it will last for a while.

Same for Bike Nashbar pumps, they have a lifetime guarantee. Had one of their top of the line L'Orange pumps from 2009, when it broke this year they took back for a full refund and I bought the newest version which seems like it will last for a while.
Floor pumps: check out SKS Hand pumps: check out Lezyne
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9EcjWd-O4jI

They clearly appreciated in value. Yep, back in 1984, they were $29.00:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/like/381444857542?ul_noapp=true&chn=ps&lpid=82

I have had two pumps: a Silca and a Blackburn. I've had the Silca for more than 30 years and the Blackburn for probably 18. I think you're a bit unfair to Blackburn because their pump has a lifetime warranty and whenever a part wears out I send it to them and they send me a replacement. They've probably sent me more in replacements then I spent on the pump. So A+ service from Blackburn. I actually feel guilty about having them send replacements anymore and will probably just buy one of their pumps when it finally goes.
Lezyne hand pump works fine. Been using Topeak Joe Blow floor pump for 16 years...only issue is that the pin in the head slips out. Never had to do a repair.
CO2 is soluble in rubber. It passes right through much faster than air, even though it is heavier.

That's about the time I got mine. Black with red letters. I'm not sure, but didn't Silca start selling Track Pumps with a plastic base, a few years before they discontinued them????....Somehow, that sticks in my head.
performance bike run of the mill floor pump of 10 years still works fine other than having to account for the gauge starting at 11

I have a black 33 year old Silca floor pump, still with the Columbus sticker and still going strong. In fact I need to replace the leather pump washer for like the 3rd time. I've never seen a reason to get anything else.

Just ordered a new gasket for my Silca brass pump head that is 30+ years old. The new ones are made of silicon or some 21st century miracle material vs. rubber. I've replaced a Silca gauge and a coupe of leather washers, otherwise they're the gift that keeps on giving...air.
As soon as I saw the title I knew there would be loads of comments. Where else on the web can you have a discuusion about bike pumps - that's why I come here every day!

I have a Silca pump sitting in the corner of my room. It was my first pump I bought... it's maybe 20 years old. It still works but I prefer a Specialized pump which is a little newer that I use everyday. As for frame pumps Park Tool makes one of the nicest low cost pumps. It's hit a few dogs and has saved many peoples CO2 fails. It's lasted about 6 years so far.

item.title: Decisions
item.dc:creator: tilford97

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
I'm pretty much with Krakatoa. I lined up in your heat at Masters in Louisville and even though I was doing good for me, you still lapped me. That was frustrating - do go from top 10 placing in my local races to getting pulled.
Jason was pretty on point, except for the disc comment (unless he was giving you some crap).
Understand about the hip, too. If it's not working for you, then just take some time to re-think cross.

Something wrong with cx courses if your starting position has such a strong influence on finishing place. Any win-competitive cx racer should be able to start at the back and finish top 10, or start in the middle and finish top 5. This isn't the chicrosscup.

Love to see you up at JingleCross. Lots of racing in a weekend. Though it might not solve the problems you describe, it's also a chance to see some old friends and IC is not a bad place to hang for a weekend.
You're not 21 any more. Be realistic.
Screw Euro's advice.

Consider a few races at lower competition level to get back into it. The Derby City Cup uses the Ohio Valley Cyclocross Series races, which includes Cat 1/2/3/4 45+ & 55+ fields. Mark Legg Compton raced in the 45+ last year and Peter Webber has dominated it this year and last year. Regain your cx legs and your confidence, then return to the Elite race if you feel up to it.

Steve I know you're always active generally, but I don't recall ever seeing you post about any kind of specific off the bike training you do... you know, yoga, core work, weight work, calisthenics, plyo etc... do you ever do that kind of stuff? Might be a good idea for overall resilience and general health and injury prevention.
I bet if you raced in jeans, you'd have better luck. Like jeans Iceman guy.

I remember the Sorrento Cyclocross in 1984 (San Diego). Not long after the S/F, there is this long, steep, rutted, bumpy downhill (on hard-packed dirt, embedded with smooth rocks) and then an immediate steep uphill. Everyone "I" knew would take the downhill slow (taking care to stay upright), dismount at the bottom, and then run up the other side.
YOU, on the other hand, BOMBED down that hill and just rolled-over the other side, with maybe a crank turn (or two). You were fearless. You literally decimated the rest of the field. One of my friends broke his collarbone on that downhill. That was my first true experience of seeing the difference between "the rest of us" and the truly elite riders. It was humbling to watch.
I think you need to sit back and take some friggin inventory, dude!
You can get reasonably low USAC points (<160) by doing regional masters races for a bit without the effort it'd take in a P/1/2 race.
Des Moines this Sat and Sun

Thankfully, Steve, you live in probably the best location to very quickly/easily/cheaply reverse your ranking situation. If I was your CX coach, I'd tell you to go to Jingle Cross and plan on doing 4 races. Do all 3 UCI races and pick one of the old guys races (given the # of racers and amount of points floating around the Midwest, you could probably do 3 old guys races and 1 UCI race and have a similar outcome but by doing the UCI races you could tell yourself: "Steve, you are going to probably get your butt kicked; try not to break any equipment, or yourself, have fun and make sure you finish." It would be much harder to stomach getting beat or broken by some random 58 yr old guy). Given your 2 results in Louisville, you could very easily come out of Iowa with 5 total races with points less than 175. When that is done, and assuming you are having fun, target some old guy races (Colorado has some many guys with low points this would be a logical choice). Odds are you'll start in the first 3 or 4 rows, which is close enough to win those races given your background. Before you know it your ranking will be around 140 or lower, which would put you in position to do well or win Nats if you get serious (and probably a disc bike). Godspeed.
Kansas state championships are in Lawrence on Sunday. Maybe do a local race for once.
Try Collagen supplements if not doing so already, helps heal/strengthen ligaments & tendons

Steve
Keep racing cross and pick theones you like.
Now. Whaaaaat happened to your home in East Topeka? Holy house-squatting! Please tell us more.
this post sounds like all u wanted was a bunch of your follwers to tell you dont worry, you're still great... you been racing 40 years.. you should know what to do..
Yeah, disc brakes will solve it...

You didn't do any regular PT after your shoulder and hip injuries/surgeries, did you? You just rode your bike, so those are the only muscles that "came back." PT would have worked all of the muscles, not just the bike riding muscles. Go to a PT twice a week, and race some cross too!

item.title: Kansas State Cyclocross Today
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: I found out that the Kansas State Cyclocross Championships is today in Lawrence. Â I really hadn't been searching for a race, thinking that this wasn't a weekend for that. Â But, I like racing races for titles and it is close, plus most all my friends from around here will be there, so other than being iffy for racing cross, I don't have many reasons not to go. Â You know things aren't exactly right when you're looking for reasons not to go race. Anyway, I put together a 2nd cross bike yesterday, so I was standing most of the day. Â Sometimes that is bad, but other times I feel fine, so I guess it is what it is. I put the old Ultegra Di2 on the bike. Â It is externally routed cable, so it looks a little jerry-rigged. Â I took the sprinter shifters off my road bike, but they wouldn't plug into the old Ultegra shifters. Â Shit. Â These would be so good for cross, especially at the start. I only glued on two tires, so that didn't take that long. Â It surprises me how much glue and rim tape it takes to glue on one tire. Â But, gluing cross tires onto carbon rims is not something to be stingy with. So, I have two bikes even though I have no intention and hopefully only have use for one. Â Keith Walberg's team 360 is putting on the race and he was over at the course all day yesterday to help set. Â He said the course is super long, nearly 2 miles and there is only one dismount, which is good for me right now. I'm heading over to Lawrence pretty soon, even though the Elite race isn't until 3pm. Â I need to ride a bunch on the bike to see how it handles. Â Plus, I haven't really been just hanging out at a cross race recently, so it seems like a nice way to spend Sunday. Alright, I'll let you know how it goes.   I don't spend days gluing tires, but use a lot of glue and rim tape. I leave a loop of wire next to the shift lever in case the lever or bars move, so it doesn't pull the wire out of the shifter.   I file pads a rap to expose new rubber and make sure there isn't a metal imbedded This was the pad before

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I see you are running the TRP Mini-Vs. Wondered what you thought.
Nice comment, but you didn't have to yell so loud.
SEEMS LIKE ALL YOU CAN DO IS PAY YOUR DUES LIKE EVERYONE ELSE AND SEE HOW FAR YOU CAN RECOVER. WITH YOUR PEDIGREE IT SHOULD BE A SUCCESS. BEST OF LUCK

item.title: Kansas State Cyclocross Champion
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: The above post title is accurate, but misleading in my view. Â I am the 2015 Kansas State Cyclocross Champion, but I didn't win the race yesterday. Â Not even close. Joseph Schmalz won the cyclocross states yesterday in Lawrence, but there is some obscure rule in the USAC rulebook that says that a D3 Pro can't win an Elite state championship. Â Since Joseph rides for the Hincapie Development Team, which is registered as a professional road team, he somehow disqualifies himself from being state champion. Â Weird rule. Â He is from Kansas and won the race, thus, in my opinion, is Kansas State Champion. Whatever, it really doesn't matter. Â The race was fun, super competitive and had a super turnout. Â There were a ton of really young kids, like kids on 24" wheeled bikes, racing super fast. Each and every category had a pretty good field. Â The Pro 1/2 field was probably the smallest with less than 20, but Kansas what was small quantity, the quality was pretty high. The race was good. Â I had an okay day, which surprised me. Â I'm not familiar with my pre-cross sensations since I haven't raced a cross race for 2 years. Â Now I've done 3. Â It might take a while understanding how I need to feel before such an intense effort begins. I got to the race pretty early. Â I wanted to spend the entire day at the race. Â Watching my friends race and just soaking up the atmosphere. Â I'm glad I made that decision. Anyway, pre-riding, way early went badly. Â I flatted a brand new front tire the first lap I rode. Â I hate spending so much effort glueing on a new tire and having it flat so fast. Â  I didn't feel that much better riding. Â The course was long, nearly 2 miles, with lots of corners and off-camber sections that were tricky. Â I wasn't only physically feeling off, my handling skills were lacking too. I did a lot of laps between races, but still wasn't feeling it. Â About an hour before the race, I went to the get some coffee and when I had finished that, I felt way better for some unexplainable reason. Â Physically and mentally it was like I was on a different level. Â That was weird. Â Good weird, but still weird for me. So,I was okay for the race. Â I screwed up the start and missed my pedal more than once and was buried coming off the start concrete. Â I was 10 guys back and it was hard moving up quickly because the course was tight. Â My team mate, Benn Stover got the hole shot and he can go pretty quick for a lap or two. Â Joseph and Shadd Smith, who had just finished 2nd both days in Louisville in his Master's race, was up there. Â I was hoping those guys didn't separate themselves before I got up to the front. I slowly got up there, pretty much right after Joseph had jumped away from the group. Â  Shadd kept the pressure on and seemed to be keeping Joseph in check. Â But Joseph had a flat and was just trying to get to the pit. He got to the pit in the lead, but came back out at the end of the large group. And the group was big. Â At the time it was 7 guys. Â Me, Joseph, Shadd, my team mates Brian Jesen and Garrick Valverde, plus Briton Kusiak and Aaron Ewell. Â All pretty good cross racers that seemed to be going pretty well. Â The course was tight enough to keep it tight. Â Plus, the wind played a big part, blowing for the south at one 30 mph. Â There were a couple long stretches on grass, plus the long pavement section, that went directly into the headwind. Â This made the race way more tactical. Joseph didn't hang around long, maybe another lap. Â He jumped from the front and I stayed with him maybe a minute and was way over my limit. Â His jump split the group up, but I wasn't too far ahead of Shadd and company, so we were back together soon. Then it became interesting. Â There were 5 of us left. Â Garrick put in a super fast lap and I jumped up to him, but Shadd got us too pretty quickly. Â And this is how it kept going. Â Brian and Britton would yo-yo off the back and we attached each other. Â I kept a lookout for Brian, and tried to slow the field down so he could get back on. Â Each time he put in a good attack, which softened Shadd up a tad each time. Coming into the final lap, there were still 5 of us. Â Brian hit the pavement first and jumped hard. Shadd was right on him, but I was gapped a little. Â Luckily for me, Brian looked back and saw that I wasn't connected and sat up. Â  I had a good head of steam going and just went right by the group when we hit the grass. Â Brian was at the front still and I was pretty sure he would get to the next corner behind me. That was enough for me to separate myself and then we just raced. Â Shadd was on his own. Â Then Garrick behind him, then Britton and Brian. Â I felt pretty good the last lap. Â Like I said above, it was a long lap, over 7 minutes, so I monitored my efforts. Â There were just enough off-camber, tricky sections to get some rest. I came in just a few seconds ahead of Shadd, probably close to a minute behind Joseph, but that is just a guess. Â The best rider won, for sure, but the next places could have gone many different directions. Â It was fun racing. Â I didn't see anyone fall, which is surprising considering the course. It was blustery at the finish, the temperature having dropped some. Â Everyone was in pretty good spirits. Â I had missed the unique camaraderie that is a staple of cyclocross. We all got together after, did the awards and headed over to FreeState Brewery to have dinner. Â The TradeWind cross guys are pretty fun. Â Some pretty good, enthusiastic young guys in Ben Stover and Garrick Valverde, plus Brian, Matt and I. Â Joseph came too. Â Pretty tight-knit group. Â Pretty good day. Catherine did her first cross race in 3 years. Â She was great. Â She rode the master's women and was in a dual the whole way. Â She finally got into the lead on the final lap and won at the end. Â She was relieved I think. Â There is so much apprehension involved in athletics when you've been out of it for a while. Â It was a good start for her. Â She had to jump in the car, head to the airport and fly to Seattle to work this week. Â Pretty full meal deal day for her. I feel pretty good about yesterday. Â I did some high speed dismounts, which worried me. Â I was going okay, not super, but not bad. I am not crippled today. Â  I have more confidence, which is always important, especially in cyclocross. Â It's going to be slow and the relearning process is going to be interesting. Â I haven't seen any mud yet, no ice or snow. Â You have to have so many skills in the sport, it is crazy. Next weekend, there are a couple races in Oklahoma. Â The race on Saturday has 2K to win.Â  The total prize list is $15,000. Â I think I'm going to go there and take a couple more baby steps. [caption id="attachment_37658" align="aligncenter" width="600"] The start of the 3's race. Matt is breathing out of his nose. The kid ahead of him in the green I heard is 16 and is tearing it up in cross and off-road MTB.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37660" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Catherine leading on the last lap.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37654" align="aligncenter" width="476"] Brian and me going hard.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37657" align="aligncenter" width="450"] The podium.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37655" align="aligncenter" width="450"] The "real State Championship" podium.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37656" align="aligncenter" width="449"] On the last lap.[/caption]

Please 'scuse me, because I've been out-of-competition for a while...
When did they stop distinguishing between amateur and pros in state championships? Also, they didn't used to have "categories" for those over 18. If you were a Cat 4 and thought you had the chops to win the Sr. Men's event, by all means, go ahead and register. I don't even think they had masters categories at districts back in the day.
So what's the "prize" for a Cat3 state champion; a state championship jersey (or perhaps an upgrade to Cat2)?

Feeling off. Havnt raced, bad hip, flat tire,,,blah blah blah........oh look, PODIUM.....Good job Man!! Keep it up, love the posts every day. Hoping you come to Seattle sometime, would love to shake your hand!

Hola Steve
Everyone no's that coffee makes you feel good. Especial the coffee Colombian!

Imo, if a racer is ineligible to have his/her results count then he/she shouldn't be allowed to even race. I understand that you wanna race against the best of the best but in this case it kind of waters down the fact that you are state champion. Just $.02
As always, thanks for the post! I always enjoy these race reports and esp the photos.

When I was a racer and now as an observer the idea of too many categories was always troubling. I always wanted to see the best 50 guys that showed up for a race to just race agaisnt each other.
Now that the peak of racers has passed we are left with a bunch of 20 rider fields. Not only can you feel hollow about being State Champ what about the State Champions in the 40+, 50+. Is the winner of the 50+ really the best 50+ guy? Won't know because you did the open race.
Minnesota State Champs did an interesting concept. One day was only age group racing for State titles while the second day was strictly categories racing for State Champs.
