like my dad said, father time is a mother fuc er.. reaction time aint there, injuries dont heal, or take forever.. everything just isnt the same.. you ought to just do road races.. less crashes than crits or mt bike racs or cross races.. why dont you ever do time trials? just about every state has a time trial series all summer.. do 1 a week all summer.. 10miles or -20miles or a -40k.. i dont think other that a hill climb at jo martin you ever posted about a time trial.. no crashes in those..
Steve! Turn around! http://cx.cxmagazine.com/wp-content/uploads/2015/12/LoganOwen.jpg
How is Michael's roof? Plenty of weather to test the patch since you did it.
RB- That kid, Caleb Swartz, was killing it the whole weekend. I have a short video of him running up Mt. Krumpet on Sunday. He was flying. I'll try to post it here soon.

RGTR - You don't have to replace everything every weekend. This was an extreme. I don't think I'm changing anything except the brake cables, which is a hassle. The real upside to hydraulic disk brakes and electronic shifting is that all you have to worry about is your chain and bearings. The power washers do a number on bearing. All of them - headset, bottom bracket, and hubs. The really just spray dirty water into them. And your bikes are getting powerwashed up to 8 times or more a day. Not good.
Kent - Dillon is a super kid and I'm glad I got to watch him for a full race on Sunday. He was going good, riding smart and moving up. Glad he is following in your footsteps.
Would love to see that video you have of Caleb Swartz running up Mt Krumpit at Jingle Cross. I was ankle deep in mud working the pits all weekend so miss out on watching him race.

item.title: Squirreling Away the Winter (and it is not even winter yet)
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: I have been pretty done since coming back from the cyclocross stage race in Iowa. Â Haven't really been sleeping much and my hamstrings are toast. Â I was going to try to keep up the running, but haven't even thought about attempting that yet. I'm not stressed about it really. Â I don't have to be going good for a month and think I have a pretty good base for it now, just need to tweak it a little and I should be fine. Â One thing I have going for me athletically is that I don't really lose form over the winter much, if I keep riding. And many times I just go better and better. Â I think it is because there aren't any allergens around to mess me up. Â But there is always the potential for getting sick. Â I just watched an interview with Sven Nys and he said he is heading down to Spain to train for a week, before the Christmas time races and he said that getting sick is his biggest worry. I've been trying to catch up on stuff. Â Today I am riding over to Lawrence and getting my AWD van. Â I left it over there to have a friend, Marcos, look at it and diagnose a couple issues. Â I'm pretty okay with automobile repair, just suck at figuring out what need to be fixed. Â I really don't suck at it, but I'm not nearly as good as actually doing the repair. The AC quit working a month ago, which really isn't a big deal, other than the defrost works a lot worse. Â He said that it was the clutch, which is a replaceable part. Â It is a little tricky changing it, but it doesn't look that hard. Â Plus after changing the sway bars links, I think I now need sway bar bushings. Â I should have just put those it when I had it apart last week. Plus I need to mess around with the injector wiring harness, which is buried and might be a longer job. Â This model van tend to have issues with these and I'm just going to try to fix it and not replace it. Anyway, riding over there is just a hour and a half. Â On gravel. Â Pretty much my go to ride nowadays. Â It is supposed to be nearly 60 later in the afternoon, but I have to drive to Kansas City to get the clutch, so need to leave pretty soon, when it is still cool. I don't really like riding with things covering my knees, so will do just about anything to avoid it. I ride down to the 40's with bare legs most of the time, which I realize is unusual compared to the norm. I was thinking about how in the winter I am always just trying to catch up with what I've put off during the season. Â But when the season is the winter too, then that gets a little tough. I was watching all the squirrels in my front yard collecting acorns and was thinking about how industrious they are. Â I bet we'd all be way more industrious, too, if we had to collect all the food we ate the next 4 months and stored it. Â Not collect by going to the grocery store, but by growing it, picking it, canning it and storing it. Â Like the old days. I just read that one of the reasons we, as we Americans, are so fat is that we eat an average of 200 calories more each time we eat out. Â Mutiple that by the number of times an average American eats out during a week/month/year, and you'll get a big number, which translates into a big waist. Our cats are all putting on their winter weight. Â I'm not sure why they do that? Â Must be just a built in mechanism. Â They get as much food as the want and don't have to go outside if they don't want to, so it seems like they don't need the extra weight. Â But they are all bulking up and they aren't eating out. Â  Just biological I guess. Okay, I'm just blabbing here. Â Putting off getting dressed and getting a little cold. Â Better get to it. [caption id="attachment_37851" align="aligncenter" width="450"] I changed the sway bar links last week.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37852" align="aligncenter" width="450"] They were toast. Should of just done it all then.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37850" align="aligncenter" width="600"] This is what I'm buying and, hopefully, installing today. It is a clutch that runs the air conditioner. Changing it is still a little expensive, but you don't have to recharge the system like you would have to if I put in a new compressor. Plus, I hate wasting perfectly good things. FIxing is always more rewarding than replacing.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37849" align="aligncenter" width="544"] There are tons of squirrels around this year. Sometimes we have 5-10 at a time in our yard. Could only get two in the picture this morning.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: JB: Killing by torture no matter how much of a pest they are to YOU is wrong!

Florida is looking good - we head there tomorrow .... No legs or arms or undershirts required by the looks of it pre Xmas Come down - Just bring a fixed wheel roadie with a 66 inch gear because like the lack of clothes required there is a lack or hills and corners ;) It's still better than fixing Patty Cakes bathroom up ;)
Heading to Dallas or Waco the next two weeks for CX racing? Resolution Cross Cup in Garland is a good one!

Hey Steve, I replaced the Ac clutch on my VW a few years ago. The AC experts at local garages were telling me I needed a new compressor and I was looking at $1800. I ended up just replacing the clutch mechanism for $130 and it's brand new, works great. A bit of a headache to get the circlips off, mainly because of where the compressor is. As you said you leave it connected and don't have to drain the refrigerant. Of course this means you have to work on it in the engine compartment which is a bit of a headache. I used these guys for the parts. http://www.acclutches.com/ac-clutches-and-parts/ Good luck.

Yeah Andy - I watched a youtube video on my exact situation. There are two circlips to remove and it is tight. Not nearly as easy as just pulling out the compressor. I have the refrigerate and access to a vacuum, but like I said, fixing is better than replacing in my mind. I'm not saving much money doing it this way and it is a harder repair, but that is just life.

Tanner - Trying to figure that out right now. I most likely will do at least one of those racing. Right now I have a ticket to San Francisco on Friday. There is a race on the Master's Worlds course on Saturday.

Squirrels. I used to think they were cute and fuzzy. Then one of the little bastards made a nest in my airbox on my '01 F250 diesel (similar to your Van!). She chewed up the filter into a nice little cozy and just left it there waiting for me to turn on the engine and suck it into the turbo. I don't know what made me check the filter that day, it had been sitting for a while and I just decided it would be good to check it.
Now they're trying to find a way into the roof of my house. My dogs suck at catching them. I will soon rain down terror on them in the form of a .22 caliber pellet. Dogs will make sure their suffering is at a minimum. I tried to appease them, they kept infiltrating. It must be done.
Bonus: I will get to eat my own pecans for a change.

They built a nest in my attic. They would always return there in the middle of the night when the temps got below 18 degrees. The liked to talk and chatter at about 2 am. We called it "party attic". It would drive us crazy! They would also return there to die in the summer, and the fist clue was the smell. Tough to find them with 12 inches of insulation; and they would usually croak out by the eaves which made them really tough to get too, and no fun when it was 140 degrees up there. I could get ahold of their little corpses with a golf ball retriever. Pulled a ton of sticks and leaves out of the attic, just an unbelievable amount really. We finally had it all sealed up. They chewed a few wires up there too before we closed it down for them. So be careful Steve!

I don't think the neighbors would like me firing a gun in the 'hood, and I don't want poisoned squirrels dying in my inaccessible attic, so I live trap them and then drop the trap and all into a rain barrel for a couple of minutes. Head shots would be more fun. They'll come back if you try to relocate them. Damn squirrels. I used to like them. I really do like animals in general, just not wild ones relieving themselves on the ceiling above my daughter's bedroom.

Squirrels destroyed my roof 10 years ago. Not only do they have their babies up there, they also use it for a bathroom. What was even worse was the hole allowed a raccoon to get in there.
I need to start wearing thin knee warmers in the mid 50's. Thermal ones in the mid 40's.

Did you mean 2000 calories average for "eating out"? I don't doubt that.
Tubbification of America.

What is a more humane way? I am open to suggestions.
Keep in mind, squirrels have been shown to travel 20 miles (across rivers/interstates) back to their home turf and chew right back through the side of the now-patched house to get back in. Killing them is the only way to ensure they don't get back in your house.
Poison: they die in your attic (and they suffer for longer) Gun: not safe in residential area

Youtube: The single best product to arise from the mayhem of the technology revolution. It serves so many different roles in my life now. Hmm, I'm in the mood to hear the music from The Little Rascals. Ciao!
You need to relocate them to the other side of a water source (such as a river, or stream). I've never understood why people drown them.
People have done that (after painting a dot on their tale) and they've gotten back. I know I've seen a squirrel running across small bridges.

Wow I've never had to take them more than four miles. Just open up the live trap so they can see a tree and that's always the end of it! No returns accepted in the last fifteen years. I only take them into the next drainage because I'm headed in that direction for something else.
So either my squirrels just aren't as salmon-like as all you guys' or else the predators are getting them first? And there are lotsa foxes around here. Every few years I willl get rid of the entire bloodline that knows about how to get up into my attic and then I will get about five months of peace before another one shows up.
They have no resistance to honey laced peanut butter and the only issue on the entrapment side is having a skunk get in there first. Because skunks will play dead for days at a time until you deploy a two inch firecracker just to clear out the trap.

item.title: Death by Fondue
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Yesterday I rode over to Lawrence on gravel, go my van and drove over to Kansas City to retrieve a car part. Â I was driving on Hwy. 24, with is a Kansas highway, not interstate. Â I had underdressed a little and didn't really feel that good anyway. I felt a little bonky and decided to stop at a Caseys General Store and get a slice of pizza and coffee. Â Their pizza isn't have bad, but their coffee could improve some. It got me thinking about an experience I had in Switzerland right around 30 years ago that still cracks me up. Back in 1985, I had ridden the World Road Championships in Italy and then drove up to Switzerland with my team director, Michael Fatka and Trudi. Â We were going there because Michael was looking to get a dog, a Swiss Appenzeller, sort of like a Bernese Mountain dog. Anyway, we were hanging out in Appenzell, a region just east of Zurich, close to Austria, looking at farms for these puppies. Â It was a good adventure. Â Super scenic area to ride a bike. Â You should make it a point to go there if you have a chance. One evening we decided to go for fondue, because the region has a famous cheese. Â So we go over to this pretty expensive fondue restaurant and there is a wait, but the hostess tells us, in German, to go to the bar. Â So we go to the bar and order a beer each. Â She said it was going to be close to 30 minutes. Just after we got our beer, the hostess came over and told us that our table was ready. Â So we took our beers and started to follow her. Â She saw that and told us we could not, absolutely could not, bring the beers to the table to have with the fondue. Trudi can speak German, but the woman was speaking Swiss German and she explained to Trudi that the cold beer and hot cheese would kill us. Â Yes, she said kill us. Her explanation was that the cold beer would harden up the cheese in our stomachs and that we would get sick and die. So, we had to finish our beer in the bar and have warm white wine with the fondue. I made a lot of good Swiss friends over the years and each and every time I ask them what they think about the idea of drinking cold beer with fondue. Â Not one has said anything different than the hostess. I have a friend, Trudi Karrer, who I stay with near Zurich, and saw just a couple months ago at the Richmond World Road Championships. Â She told me for sure you would die. My friend, Thomas Frischknecht, who came to the US when he was 19 and is a smart guy, answered similarly. Â Thomas said you might not die, but you'd get really sick. My best argument to them is what is the difference between fondue and pizza? Â Both are bread covered with melted cheese. Â And we drink plenty of cold beer with pizza. My rationale is that once food gets into your stomach, it eventually gets to 98.6 degrees, or whatever your body temperature is. Â It really doesn't matter how you mix it because it all gets to the same temperature. Of course, you can shock your system by ingesting a ton of super cold stuff. Â I remember drinking a huge fresh fruit slush at Sonic after a hot ride and the whole way back to my house, I could feel the skin on over my stomach and it was super cold. Â I thought that was creepy. Â But I would have no problem eating pizza and drinking a slush, which is just about the coldest thing I can think of to drink. Anyway, I never could, or can convince, a Swiss person that fondue and beer won't make you ill, or worst case scenario, kill you. Â  It must be something that they were taught from childhood. All of them. Â And it seems to have over ridden critical thinking. Â Funny.

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: And if I had to wait an hour before swimming so I wouldn't cramp. I wouldn't had much of a grade school, HS, and college swim career either. Now drinking beer with ice cream may cause you to explode or burp a lot.
If this is true, I have a lot of people to invite over to the house this weekend for a cold one and fondue. Wonder if Donald Trump is free this weekend...

http://www.dw.com/en/zurich-study-settles-longstanding-fondue-beverage-debate/a-14731202
They studied wine and schnapps consumption, not beer, but concluded that alcohol slows down digestion and thus might cause reflux. No mention of death, but they did say they needed to do another study, this time using Coke because of the persistent rumor that Coke & fondue = death. "Vader, however, admitted it might be hard finding participants for a study into what is widely misconceived to be a deadly practice."
i'm totally off fondue from now on.
I thought I remembered something about Kris and a slush and getting sick but I may be thinking of someone/something else.
It's like the Korean belief that having a fan in the room will cause asphyxiation. Look it up, it's called "fan death."
You'll shoot your eye out kid!
Wonderful post...thank you!

Steve I fell strongly that the only thing to do is Test it. You should make a Fondue and have it with really cold beer. Maybe have some friends over and really put it to the test. Of course you will need to post about.
Feel
Geez...where I come from, hot cheese and cold beer is comfort food. Now tequila and jalapenos...that's a whole different game !
Steve, did Michael get Gaylen, my favorite dog, on that trip?
I get that when I tell people that press fit bottom bracket bearings are stupid. I get the same thing when I tell them that nothing beats a CK old school headset.
Does American chain fondue restaurant The Melting Pot serve beer? That should clear things up definitively.

This is just an old muth. My (Swiss) father used to tell us this when we had our fondues every few months as kids. However, it is just an old wives tale, and I have tested it many times. There is NO truth to this story.
Do doubt a myth perpetuated by the wine industry.

Remember when Lemond was out with Kathy and a photographer snapped a shot of the two of them eating ice cream? The European public was doubly horrified. First that he was ingesting ice cream during the TDF. Second that he was hanging with his own wife (and presumably having relations with her during the Tour). Not long after, he got "caught" playing charity golf tournament. Cyclists apparently shouldn't stand up and walk very much during the racing season.
Leading cause of death in Wisconsin.

i remember my older german relatives thought a drink with ice in it would upset your stomach...
When i was young you could never get ice in your drink in germany. I thought it was super wierd...

Fondue and cold beer is a killer combination.
All kidding aside, you will die.

In Switzerland many years ago we stopped in Gruyere, the home of "swiss" cheese. Not the crap you see in US supermarkets with holes in it, this was the real thing. There RACLETTE is the thing - melted Gruyere over all kinds of stuff. Being a dumb American, I insisted on drinking "Vino Americano" which is Coca-Cola. Our Swiss friends were aghast, telling me I would have the mother-of-all gut aches if I insisted on drinking Coke instead of the local white wine. I paid them no mind...but paid big time that night with....the mother-of-all gut aches!!! I've enjoyed RACLETTE a few times since, ALWAYS with white wine... with no troubles.
Don't forget to invite Hillary

Steve-all through your post you mention all these claims that the warm fondue/cold beer will either kill you or make you sick. But nowhere do you say you tested the theory and proved them all wrong. WELL?!...

item.title: Resolution Cross - Garland, Texas
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: I've finally made a decision and am going to drive down to Dallas on Friday and race the Resolution Cross Weekend. Â It is 2 UCI C2 races and is put on byÂ Jeff Lucido, who promotes a ton of super good events and is a super cross enthusiast. Â I originally had a ticket to fly to San Franciso for the cyclocross on the Master's Worlds course, but decided to go to Texas and enjoy the weather some. I was a little worried about there not being enough guys racing the Elite events to be alright, but there seems to be a few more guys entering every day. Â I can't finish in the top 10 of either day or face disqualification for the Master's World Cyclocross Championships in January. Â Most of you know my views on that, it sucks. Â But the way I've been racing cyclocross this season, top 10 might be a challenge. Jamie Driscoll and Troy Wells, two guys that were going super fast in Iowa last weekend at Jinglecross have entered now, so Tristan should have his hands full. Â Plus a few other really fast guys. This is nearly the last weekend of UCI cross races of the season. Â If you don't have any plans, try to make your way down. Â It should be a fun time. The next weekend is two more UCI races in Waco. Â This is the last two day UCI race weekend before the holidays and Cyclocross Nationals in January. Yesterday it was a record high here in Kansas and it was 70 degrees. Â I rode nearly 80 miles. Â It was windy as it always is when it is that warm in December. Â Joseph rode over from Lawrence and Kris and I rode him the long way back to Lawrence, then back home. Â I have been feeling pretty beat since Jinglecross, but felt okay riding. Â My legs hurt but I had okay power. Â We had a 20 mph average for the ride and like I said, it wasn't easy conditions. My hamstrings have been aching the last few days. Â I'm not sure if it is from slogging up muddy hills in Iowa or automobile repair. Â Leaning into an engine compartment always does a number on hamstrings. Â Right now I'm putting in a new injector wiring harness in my AWD van. Â I self diagnosed the problem and it looks like I was right. Â Many of the wires are exposed and have to be shorting. Â It wasn't running that rough, which is mildly unbelievable. Â I was planning on fixing the harness, but it is so screwed up I ordered one next day. Â It was close to $200, but that is 1/2 price of the dealer. Â I should have it done by tomorrow if the harness shows up. Today I'm going to take a flight in aÂ KC-135 air refueling aircraft. Â I was invited, along with a few other guys from Topeka to go. Â They are going to be refueling some B-2 bombers, (stealth bombers) Â from Whiteman AFB. Â It should be an exciting and memorable experience. Â I'll post some photos tomorrow. Â  [caption id="attachment_37863" align="aligncenter" width="640"] The wires of the injector harness were toast. This should be a recall situation.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37864" align="aligncenter" width="480"] I had to take a lot of stuff off the top of the engine, so figured I'd change the valve cover gaskets while I have access.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37865" align="aligncenter" width="480"] Kris and Joseph out riding yesterday.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: I have to agree with Steve. Age-graded means just that. The fact that some are better than others is a hard nut to swallow. The same one swallowed when you subtract X number of years from the category and you were all competing as Seniors. Frankly, I don't think there should be Masters races under the age of 50+ We already separate riders by ability, why the need to further do it by age, except to add to the number of races per day, which always shortens the length of the races on that day.

Thurlow was the first ex-pro to race veteran/masters races after he got the rule changed. (He came back crying after the La Vie Claire days)â€¦â€¦â€¦.Really think you could go toe to toe with Vito Di Tano or Adri Vanderpoel? You won't have to--- we might be the only country in the world which allows pros/ex-pros into veteran/masters racing. Shouldn't have to explain the reason for that :~)
That Jog Mate jersey has held up pretty well!
Yeah - Those were nearly the original Verge jerseys and that was a 5 color edition. Colors are still really bright.
Dallas area weather Saturday: High 72, wind 18-20 mph, 90% chance of rain.
Remember to sandbag it to avoid scoring any points before worlds!
Steve, I got an e-mail today from the promoter stating they "postponed" the 2016 event till 2017/ You may want to check that out before you book too much stuff.
That is for Masters Worlds.

And you won't see this at cxmagazine.com for a day or so. Because they aren't quite there.
And CX is dead.

And after the sandbagging comes the cherrypicking, right? At least that's what we used to call finagling your way into a racing category where you have a better chance to win. If I was a lower-category Masters racer unable to race in the UCI class and found myself racing in the Master class against a guy who could and did race there, but cleverly made sure he finished out of the top 10 just to show up and beat the likes of me, I'd be tempted to jam a nail into his tire on the start line!!!
http://www.cxmagazine.com/2016-uci-masters-cyclocross-world-championships-san-jose-cancelled

Larry-I assume you are applying you comment to me. It is the World Championships. I didn't make the rules. Seems to me that to win an age group World Championship, the qualification would be by age. But, that isn't the way the UCI see it. So, if you happen to line up next to me in San Jose, keep your nails to yourself.

A former pro is never a true master. Master implies amateur doing it purely for the love of the sport and not for reward. Former pros have such a huge advantage from having trained full-time for some years that regular amateurs can hardly compete on a diet of 10 hrs/week.
Masters is not just by age. Why would anyone who raced at Elite Road Worlds, CX Worlds and MTB Worlds have any interest in racing a masters champs? Leave it to the old farts with jobs and families.
Sandbagging races to avoid collecting points is cat 4 stuff.
While I really enjoy reading this blog Carlos has hit the nail on the head. Enough with all this Masters stuff Steve.
Don't hold back Steve...Worlds for Masters is cancelled! Go get you some UCI points!
Steve, how do you finance all your travels ? Just curious. Also, remember Dan Chew from Pittsburgh ? Mr. mega-mile man. Any memories or stories?

Thanks to Thurlow, ex-pro riders can ride veteran/masters events in the USA. Doesn't happen in the rest of the world. Ex-pros there just fade away, race top category until they can no longer influence the race outcome/not do teamwork/ride in the peloton.

Uncle-Why thanks to Thurlow? There are a ton of guys that are racing pretty much full time over the age of 40 now. Thurlow is probably making more money riding his bike than 90% of the D3 pros in this country.
So....why DO ex-professional racers compete in amateur races?

item.title: Pretty Interesting Day
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Yesterday I was all over the place. Â I was trying to secure some auto parts, had an invitation to fly on a B-2 bomber refueling plane and then found out that I've been training mostly for nothing. The day turned out alright though. Â Got the parts and installed them. Â Pretty rewarding fix. Made it to the base in time to make the orientation meeting and then fly most the way across Kansas and back with 3 B-2 bombers. But the bummer was that Master's Cyclocross Worlds in San Jose was cancelled. Â I don't have enough information about it and am a little too riled up about the whole thing, so I'm not going to comment much other than it totally sucked and someone needs to accept the blame and apologize. Â I didn't see anyone doing that yesterday. The highlight of the day was the special flight on a K-135 refueling jet based here in Topeka. Col. Chuck Remboldt is a commander at the 190th here in Topeka and also a super enthusiastic cyclist. Â He got together a bunch of guys from the area, mostly bike race associated people and took us up on one of their training flights. Â It took a few hours, but was well worth the time. I'm not that much into the military, I have to say. Â But after hanging out with these guys, it made me rethink some of my beliefs about the military. Â The guys that are responsible for these jets are some of the most competent people I've met. Â They take their jobs very seriously, but have lots of extra time to explain what they are doing to us. Â Pretty down to earth folks. We flew over near Dodge City and back, meeting up with 3 B-2 bombers and refueled them. They practice this all the time when they aren't deployed in the middle east or elsewhere. Â  The guys doing this are the guys that you'd want to do it. Â I had never taken this into consideration much. Â It wasn't much like flying a commercial airline. Â You could walk around, go into the cockpit or down to the refueling pod at the back of the plane. Â Pretty generally do just about anything you want. There are only 20 B-2 bombers in existence now. Â And any number of them might be grounded at any one time. Â So seeing three of them at one place isn't a normal occurrence, especially from just a few dozen feet away, at 30,000 feet. My friend Rod Lake texted me that it is a bucket list thing I just did, but you wouldn't even know it to put on your list because it is so crazy. Â I couldn't have said it better. Â It was an once in a lifetime experience, I think. Â Pretty cool. Anyway, I'm still heading down to Texas today. Â I'm not thinking much about not racing after Nationals. Â I'm not too stoked about racing Masters Cyclocross Nationals. Â I don't have anything to prove there and honestly it isn't my focus. Â Maybe I'll get enough points to qualify to ride the Elite race. Â But starting that race at the very back would be thankless really. Â  Not sure there is a solution that I'll be happy with here. Okay, I need to pack, maybe try to ride a little or something and get driving. [caption id="attachment_37873" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Engine yesterday morning.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37871" align="aligncenter" width="600"] The K-135 refueling jet. I believe it is a modified 707. It holds 200,000 lbs of fuel. Pretty amazing.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37874" align="aligncenter" width="592"] This is Col. Chuck Remboldt. Super nice guy.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37875" align="aligncenter" width="600"] And this is a B-2 bomber getting about ready to get refueled at 30000 feet. They are based at Whiteman AFB in Missouri.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content: Move to Russia. I'll buy you a few pencils as a parting gift.

You dropped the Bomb on me, Bay-bee!
Stay tuned!
Those are cool pictures!

http://www.cxmagazine.com/2016-uci-masters-cyclocross-world-championships-san-jose-cancelled
There is a link to the story about the cancellation. Those pictures from the plane are very cool, Gordo

"Iâ€™m not that much into the military, I have to say."
the problem is that most peoples exposure to the "military" is thru movies. civilians often think military = trigger-pullers, rambos, dim-witted macho-men and war-criminals when in fact only a small % of the military manpower is "at the sharp end of the spear". the biggest % of military personnel and dollars are associated with logistics. that's the supply chain, getting all the "beans, bullets, band-aids" from here out to the people that need it "at the sharp end". most people in the military are well educated, professionals, and patriots that are worthy of our respect and appreciation for their service!

Wally......you are absolutely correct in your assessment of the military. Not having much exposure to it myself, my perspective totally changed when I began working as a civilian for the Army Corps of Engineers. All officers I have met are highly educated. Most Colonels have multiple Master's Degrees. Hollywood has done a pretty poor portrayal of what and who the US Military is. The chest-thumping, arrogant, self-important persona often displayed in the movies is pure fiction. Most officers today exhibit an incredible degree of emotional intelligence along with high academic achievement. There is also a huge contingent of civilians working for the DoD, supporting the military in areas that are nor inherently military-centric. BTW....only officers (read: college educated) are allowed to be pilots in the Air Force.
thumbsup!

Our tax dollars at work. I'll never understand the reason why the US needs to spend as much on defense as the next nine biggest spending countries COMBINED! I get sick to my stomach when I think what we could be doing with the money we piss away on the dreaded "military-industrial complex" Eisenhower warned us about all those years ago.

To those critical of the "military-industrial complex", just remember that the carbonfiber frame, rims, crank, etc. you enjoy everyday are directly derived from R & D conducted by the aerospace/defense industry.
Yeah, that justifies the outlay!

I missed the sarcasm that was certainly in your comment, right? Otherwise, my bicycles are all made of metal, as in steel and aluminum, so can I have my tax dollars back? This kind of "logic" reminds me of the US space program. They spent countless dollars developing a special "space pen" with a pressurized ink canister to write in zero gravity. Meanwhile, the Russians used....a pencil.
Thanks for the nice comment Luigi, I'm happy you could spare a few minutes away from the "Trump for President" campaign to share your thoughts. Have a great day.
Larry sounds like a swell guy at parties, he knows more than everybody else and also singlehandedly shoulders the US tax burden.

item.title: Resolution Cup, Dallas, Texas - Day 1, a Bust
item.dc:creator: tilford97
item.content:encoded: Yesterday didn't go too well. Â Actually, it wasn't really that bad. Â The result, or more accurately, the non-result was pretty depressing, but I had a pretty good day all around really. I'm staying with some friends, Rod and Charlene Lake, who live south of White Rock Lake in Dallas. Â I slept pretty great, their guest room is nearly a cave, and then Charlene made an incredible breakfast of eggs, pancakes, fruit, etc. After that, I looked at the weather and realized I only had a couple hours to ride before it starting raining. Â So I jumped on my bike and rode 30 miles. Â I was just trying to get the cobwebs out from not riding for 2 days. I got a little behind and didn't leave for the race until after 2 and the course was only open for warmup from 2:30-3. Â We were a little late and I got dressed fast and got out on the course. Â I was heading first into the woods section, which had a few steep hills that were nearly impossible to walk up because of the rain. Â Then I noticed my rear tire was flat. Â Shit. Â It was a FMB and I really didn't want to get my other bike all muddy before the start. So I really didn't see all the course, but saw the general layout. Â I got the last callup, very last guy. Â This random thing isn't working out so well for me this year so far. Â I wasn't that worried since there were only 33 guys there and a long road hill for the start. I passed a bunch of guys at the start and got up to 17th early in the first lap. Â Everyone was bobbling a bunch. Â It was super slick, way slicker than Jinglecross. Â Lots of clay I think. Â I passed a couple more guys and was feeling pretty good so far. In the woods section I lost some places. Â I got the ribbon around my shifter on one hill and there was a big gap in front of me. Â  Toward the end of the first lap, there were some u-turns and I slid out on one. Â I must have either bent my derailleur hanger or just clogged my pulleys up with mud and crud, because a few hundred meters later, my rear derailleur was ripped off. Â Not really ripped off, but pulled back enough to jettison a pulley and make it unusable. I tried to get the chain to ride over the one pulley and keep riding, but no luck. Â I was so far away from a pit that it was useless to continue. Pretty depressing really. Â It was a Di2 Ultegra derailleur. Â It very easily could have been a Dura-ace, which would have been worse. So, I walked back to the pit, got Trudi and then headed to the bike wash. Â  All the power sprayers were pretty busy, so I just put the bikes into my van and drove to a car wash. I had brought a new Di2 Dura-ace derailleur with me, and a hanger, so I fixed them when I got back to Rod's house. Â Other than that, my bikes were fine. So, one down and one to go. Â It is supposed to rain all morning and clear by the race start which is 4 again. Â I hope to have a little better luck today. Â I think I was going okay, but I'm not really sure. Â I would really like a riding course, but that isn't going to be the case today. Â I has to still be muddy over there. Â Probably worse since all the other classes are doing circles there all day. Okay, that's about it. Â Jamie Driscoll won the race, Â Allen Krughoff came back from an early first lap crash to finish 2nd just 35 seconds back. Â Pretty good race for him.   [caption id="attachment_37902" align="aligncenter" width="450"] Lonely last rider.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37896" align="aligncenter" width="337"] Results. Click to enlarge.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37895" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Just after one lap. Pretty mucky.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37892" align="aligncenter" width="600"] Mangled rear mech.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37894" align="aligncenter" width="440"] Fixed.[/caption] [caption id="attachment_37893" align="aligncenter" width="440"] Rod's garage. Flying the colors.[/caption]

wp:comment.wp:comment_content:
Calvin - DId you mean when I installed the new Dura-ace derailleur did I break the chain? Or when I originally installed the Ultegra?
When I put on the Ultegra derailleur, I put on a new chain. When I changed the derailleur last night I just took off a pulley and installed the new derailleur. I don't like having more than one pin in my chains, even though I think I intellectually know that there isn't much difference, chance of failure, between one, two or three pins.
If it was a front derailleur, with a rivot and not a screw to separate the cage, then of course, I would have had to remove the chain.
Not sure the game you are playing.
you need a bike designed for mud.

Question on the rear mech. When that Ultegra was installed, was it installed without replacing the chain? Was the procedure pretty much: 1- Remove old der by pulling off cage. 2- Install new derailleur, but do not cut chain. 3- Remove top pulley, feed chain on to cage. 4- Re-install top pulley. Just wondering, kind of a game if you will.
Blue Locktite on those pulley screws.
buying new parts every week... that's why I quit racing cx.
When the mud is serious, my barcon 7 speed and single speed bikes come out. Can't tear off a rear derailleur if you don't have one.
You need a single speed, Steve!

I hate to see anyone's race ruined by mechanical issues, but I'm starting to see why the bike industry so heavily hyped 'cross as the MTB market peaked and declined. Wonder how many $150+ rear derailleurs are wrecked in muddy 'cross races each season? Back-in-the-day most 'cross bikes were equipped with low-level components since damage/destruction/wearing out was so prevalent, but things have certainly changed when competitors are using electronic shifting on bikes which see so much serious abuse. Just more to suggest cycling's truly the "new golf"?

Hey Steve, glad to hear it was just a mechanical. I was back in the woods yesterday when I heard the announcer say you had DNF'd. Watching everyone crash all day in the woods had me thinking the worst.
Good luck this afternoon!
With your FMB flat, do you take the time to repair it, or do you just add sealant to plug the pin hole?....(or did you rip it)??

Yes, thanks. Seen that before. Not a real game, just my own guessing game I guess. I agree on not popping extra connector rivets into the Shimano chain. But when the rear derailleurs fails as described here, the common cause is the pulley bolt fell out, and the reason there is because it was not tight.
